thread.title: Cyberattack on Experian may affect millions of T-Mobile customers
thread.title_full: Cyberattack on Experian may affect millions of T-Mobile customers

author: Coral Garnick
title: Cyberattack on Experian may affect millions of T-Mobile customers
text:
Cyberattack on Experian may affect millions of T-Mobile customers Originally published October 1, 2015 at 2:17 pm Updated October 1, 2015 at 3:24 pm The Bellevue wireless carrier’s CEO expresses anger at the credit services company, and says T-Mobile’s systems were not part of the breach. By Coral Garnick Seattle Times business reporter 
T-Mobile US said Thursday that approximately 15 million people may be victims of a cyberattack on one of its vendors, Experian credit-services company. 
John Legere, CEO of Bellevue-based T-Mobile, said in a statement that the hacked records include those of new applicants requiring a credit check for service or device financing from Sept. 1, 2013, through Sept. 16, 2015. 
The records include information such as name, address and birthdate, as well as encrypted fields with Social Security number and ID number (such as driver’s license or passport number), and additional information used in T-Mobile’s own credit assessments, Legere wrote in announcing the breach Thursday. 
Experian is the company that Premera used to offer two years of free credit monitoring to the 11 million people affected by a cyberattack against the health insurer. Most Read Stories
